channel.title: How to make server online?
channel.description:
Well, I got server and I want to make it online..
Verison: 637
Please help me as soon as possible you can!!

item.title: How to make server online?
item.dc:creator: @untalented untalented
item.description:
@untalented wrote:

[quote=“chains424, post:12, topic:450862”]Yes, now that you got that IP. Copy that IP and press ctr f
Then paste the ip and keep search. Everywhere you see that ip, replace it with your no-ip.[/quote]

No items matching my search ( 178.238.229.114 )

Now hmm everything is okay but…

When I press ‘Exit’ ( Before the logout ) there’s:

‘When you have finished playing Runescape … etc…’

How I can change this Runescape??

Read full topic

item.title: How to make server online?
item.dc:creator: @chains424 chains424
item.description:
@chains424 wrote:

Yes, now that you got that IP. Copy that IP and press ctr f
Then paste the ip and keep search. Everywhere you see that ip, replace it with your no-ip.

@untalented wrote:

chains424:

Try searching no-ip or server = or serverip =

I got this in loader.java:

public static String THEME = null, SCREENSHOT_PATH = null, SERVER_IP = "178.238.229.114", LOBBY_IP = "178.238.229.114", URL_PATH = null;

I chage " 178.238.229.114 " to my no-ip host?

Ok but… I can’t find any 127.0.0.1 in client.java, what I should change to make it online there?!

item.title: How to make server online?
item.dc:creator: @untalented untalented
item.description:
@untalented wrote:

[quote=“chains424, post:6, topic:450862”]It’s sometimes common for there to not be a Gui.java file. I don’t think it will harm you. Some servers don’t have them.

And search this in your client.java:

or

or

About gui.java is okay…

About client.java ( do you mean client.java in client folder? because client.java in source folder can’t see it…)

Hey!

I got something…:

In actiounsender.java I got this:

public static void sendLobbyResponse(Player player) {
	MessageBuilder bldr = new MessageBuilder();
	bldr.writeByte((byte) 0);
	bldr.writeByte((byte) 0);
	bldr.writeByte((byte) 0);
	bldr.writeByte((byte) 0);
	bldr.writeByte((byte) 0);
	bldr.writeShort(30); // member days left
	bldr.writeShort(1); // recovery questions
	bldr.writeShort(0); // unread messages
	bldr.writeShort(3229); // 3229 - lastDays
	int ipHash = Misc.IPAddressToNumber("127.0.0.1");
	bldr.writeInt(ipHash); // last ip
	bldr.writeByte((byte) 3); // email status (0 - no email, 1 - pending
	// parental confirmation, 2 - pending
	// confirmation, 3 - registered)
	bldr.writeShort(0);
	bldr.writeShort(0);
	bldr.writeByte((byte) 0);
	bldr.putGJString(player.getUsername());
	bldr.writeByte((byte) 0);
	bldr.writeInt(1);
	bldr.writeShort(1); // current world id
	bldr.putGJString("[size=12pt][b]127.0.0.1[/b][/size]");
	MessageBuilder lobbyResponse = new MessageBuilder();
	lobbyResponse.writeByte((byte) bldr.position());
	lobbyResponse.writeBytes(bldr.getBuffer());
	player.getConnection().write(lobbyResponse.toMessage());
}

I change it to my no-ip?

Read full topic

And search this in your client.java:

item.title: How to make server online?
item.dc:creator: @untalented untalented
item.description:
@untalented wrote:

[quote=“chains424, post:4, topic:450862”][quote author=untalented link=topic=553738.msg4056725#msg4056725 date=1343037813]

I made account and added a host at www.no-ip.com

Downloaded JDK 7u5 ( 1.7.0_05 )

Last thing I don’t know how to do is : Firewall…

A question, should I change anything into source ? Like I have something 127.0.0.1 should I change it to my host?

Thanks!
[/quote]

[b]If you have no-ip, change 127.0.0.1 to your no-ip. Be sure to do it the the client.java and Gui.java in the client folder. I don’t think you have the change anything in the source because people have to connect to your game through your client.

To do your firewall,

  1. Click Control Panel, if it’s not on your desktop. It should be in “Start”
  2. Right click Windows Firewall, then click open.
  3. Click Exceptions.
  4. Click Add port.
  5. Name is RSPS. Then where it says “Port Number” Add the number 43594.
  6. Click Ok.
  7. Click Add port again.
  8. Name is RSPS. Add the number 43594 in the “Port Number” spot again.
  9. This type, click “UDP”.
  10. Click Ok.

Then you are done with the firewalls part.[/b][/quote]

Firewall done, about client.java and gui.java is:

Client.java —> I can’t find any 127.0.0.1 there, so where I change?

Gui.java ----> I can’t find it, there’s no gui.java there…?

Read full topic

item.title: How to make server online?
item.dc:creator: @chains424 chains424
item.description:
@chains424 wrote:

[quote=“untalented, post:3, topic:450862”]I made account and added a host at www.no-ip.com

Downloaded JDK 7u5 ( 1.7.0_05 )

Last thing I don’t know how to do is : Firewall…

A question, should I change anything into source ? Like I have something 127.0.0.1 should I change it to my host?

Thanks![/quote]

[b]If you have no-ip, change 127.0.0.1 to your no-ip. Be sure to do it the the client.java and Gui.java in the client folder. I don’t think you have the change anything in the source because people have to connect to your game through your client.

To do your firewall,

  1. Click Control Panel, if it’s not on your desktop. It should be in “Start”
  2. Right click Windows Firewall, then click open.
  3. Click Exceptions.
  4. Click Add port.
  5. Name is RSPS. Then where it says “Port Number” Add the number 43594.
  6. Click Ok.
  7. Click Add port again.
  8. Name is RSPS. Add the number 43594 in the “Port Number” spot again.
  9. This type, click “UDP”.
  10. Click Ok.

Then you are done with the firewalls part.[/b]

Read full topic

item.title: How to make server online?
item.dc:creator: @untalented untalented
item.description:
@untalented wrote:

[quote=“chains424, post:2, topic:450862”][b]Downloading winRar

To start off, we’ll download Winrar. Winrar is a program in which you can use to extract files from .rar format,
you may download it at:

http://rarlab.com/

Downloading and Installing Java

After you have done so, we will need the latest version of the Java Development Kit found at:

http://www.oracle.com/technetwork/java/javase/downloads/index.html

Once you have selected the latest version of Java Development Kit, there will be a question asking
which platform you have, or operating system. After you have chosen your platform, you then need to
agree to the terms and services and as the next page loads, click “Download Selected with Sun Download Manager”.
From then on out, let it install and you’ll be okay.

Getting No-Ip

Well, if you’re going to have your server remain public, you’re going to have to get No-Ip.
No-Ip is a free service where you can use for websites, or servers. First, you’re going to go to:

http://www.no-ip.com/

and register an account at the site. You will then click ‘Your No-IP’ at the top right corner of the page.
Then you need to click the ‘Hosts and Redirects’ button. After you have done so, it will bring you to a page
showing your listed domains that you have added, though if you haven’t added any you’re going to click
‘Add a host’. After you have added your desired domain, you’re going to need to download the No-Ip Duc,
located if you click the button ‘Download’ on the main page. Like you have done before when downloading
Java, you’re going to need to select your operating system and let it download. Now once you have downloaded
No-Ip Duc, run it. Then all you need to check the box next to the domain you want people to log into, and
you’re good!

Setting up your Environmental Variables

Environmental variables are what allows you to run your server with Java, without it you would simple get
‘The path is not yet specified’ so this is an extremely important step. We will firstly open ‘My Computer’
and click ‘View System Information’. As you do this, a small applet displaying several tabs, and you will
select the one that says ‘Advanced’ and at the bottom, click ‘Environmental Variables’. Now what you’re going
to do, is go to your ‘Path’ and ‘Classpath’ variables and edit them.
In your Classpath variable, you’re going to take everything currently inside it and edit it with your
latest version of JDK, so right now it would be;

CLASSPATH=C:\Program Files\Java\jdk1.7.0_3\bin;%CLASSPATH%;

NOTE: The jdk1.7.0_3 may change over time. If it does, than just put in your jdk version.

After you have done the Classpath variable, you’re going to find the Path variable and add the code below
inside it.

C:\Program Files\Java\jdk1.7.0_03\bin;

NOTE: Again, the jdk1.7.0_3 may change over time. If it does, than just put in your jdk version.

Downloading a source/base

We’re going to need to have something to start from, so choose one from the Base folder.
The base you’ve downloaded could be anything you want, it’s your choice. Now when you had downloaded the
Winrar program earlier, this is where you’ll be using it. Once you have found the base of your choice,
you will need to go into the base file, and once you’ve done so you need to right click it and click ‘extract’.
Once it’s done extracting, you then are free to roam about your source.

PortForwarding

From what I’ve seen from many of you members is that PortForwarding is the hardest step to comprehend,
so I’m going to try :P. As I have an old router I may still attempt showing you how, though if anyone feels
they may give me pictures of their router that would be great.
First of all, portforwarding is merely a step to allow people connecting to your computer, but in
this case it’s for connecting to your server. We will first start off by opening your command prompt or
‘cmd’ through your startup window and typing ‘ipconfig’ which will bring up a list of details relating to
your computer, but all we really need is your default gateway. You can find your default gateway if you
scroll down, so once you have done that, open up your internet browser and type it in. This will then bring
up your router page, and you will need to click something like ‘Applications and gaming’, though mine just
says ‘Firewall’. After you have clicked this, you need to add a new user defined application. Any name is
compatible, as long as you follow the syntax shown below and set the application to ‘hosted’.[/b][/quote]

I made account and added a host at www.no-ip.com

Downloaded JDK 7u5 ( 1.7.0_05 )

Last thing I don’t know how to do is : Firewall…

A question, should I change anything into source ? Like I have something 127.0.0.1 should I change it to my host?

Thanks!

Read full topic

item.title: How to make server online?
item.dc:creator: @chains424 chains424
item.description:
@chains424 wrote:

[b]Downloading winRar

To start off, we’ll download Winrar. Winrar is a program in which you can use to extract files from .rar format,
you may download it at:

http://rarlab.com/

Downloading and Installing Java

After you have done so, we will need the latest version of the Java Development Kit found at:

http://www.oracle.com/technetwork/java/javase/downloads/index.html

Once you have selected the latest version of Java Development Kit, there will be a question asking
which platform you have, or operating system. After you have chosen your platform, you then need to
agree to the terms and services and as the next page loads, click “Download Selected with Sun Download Manager”.
From then on out, let it install and you’ll be okay.

Getting No-Ip

Well, if you’re going to have your server remain public, you’re going to have to get No-Ip.
No-Ip is a free service where you can use for websites, or servers. First, you’re going to go to:

http://www.no-ip.com/

and register an account at the site. You will then click ‘Your No-IP’ at the top right corner of the page.
Then you need to click the ‘Hosts and Redirects’ button. After you have done so, it will bring you to a page
showing your listed domains that you have added, though if you haven’t added any you’re going to click
‘Add a host’. After you have added your desired domain, you’re going to need to download the No-Ip Duc,
located if you click the button ‘Download’ on the main page. Like you have done before when downloading
Java, you’re going to need to select your operating system and let it download. Now once you have downloaded
No-Ip Duc, run it. Then all you need to check the box next to the domain you want people to log into, and
you’re good!

Setting up your Environmental Variables

Environmental variables are what allows you to run your server with Java, without it you would simple get
‘The path is not yet specified’ so this is an extremely important step. We will firstly open ‘My Computer’
and click ‘View System Information’. As you do this, a small applet displaying several tabs, and you will
select the one that says ‘Advanced’ and at the bottom, click ‘Environmental Variables’. Now what you’re going
to do, is go to your ‘Path’ and ‘Classpath’ variables and edit them.
In your Classpath variable, you’re going to take everything currently inside it and edit it with your
latest version of JDK, so right now it would be;

CLASSPATH=C:\Program Files\Java\jdk1.7.0_3\bin;%CLASSPATH%;

NOTE: The jdk1.7.0_3 may change over time. If it does, than just put in your jdk version.

After you have done the Classpath variable, you’re going to find the Path variable and add the code below
inside it.

C:\Program Files\Java\jdk1.7.0_03\bin;

NOTE: Again, the jdk1.7.0_3 may change over time. If it does, than just put in your jdk version.

Downloading a source/base

We’re going to need to have something to start from, so choose one from the Base folder.
The base you’ve downloaded could be anything you want, it’s your choice. Now when you had downloaded the
Winrar program earlier, this is where you’ll be using it. Once you have found the base of your choice,
you will need to go into the base file, and once you’ve done so you need to right click it and click ‘extract’.
Once it’s done extracting, you then are free to roam about your source.

PortForwarding

From what I’ve seen from many of you members is that PortForwarding is the hardest step to comprehend,
so I’m going to try :P. As I have an old router I may still attempt showing you how, though if anyone feels
they may give me pictures of their router that would be great.
First of all, portforwarding is merely a step to allow people connecting to your computer, but in
this case it’s for connecting to your server. We will first start off by opening your command prompt or
‘cmd’ through your startup window and typing ‘ipconfig’ which will bring up a list of details relating to
your computer, but all we really need is your default gateway. You can find your default gateway if you
scroll down, so once you have done that, open up your internet browser and type it in. This will then bring
up your router page, and you will need to click something like ‘Applications and gaming’, though mine just
says ‘Firewall’. After you have clicked this, you need to add a new user defined application. Any name is
compatible, as long as you follow the syntax shown below and set the application to ‘hosted’.[/b]

Read full topic
